facts.text: Area of Kozhikode was originally within the State of Madras, but by the States Reorganisation Act was transferred to the State of Kerala. The Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 continued to apply.
Assessment period for the purposes of the turnover in dispute is 1952-53.
By an order dated March 27, 1954 the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Kozhikode, imposed sales tax on the respondent on a net turnover of Rs. 12,56,178-14-0.
Appeal taken against that order to the Commercial Tax Officer was dismissed.
On March 15, 1956 a notice was issued by the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes against the assessee proposing to determine the escaped turnover for the period of assessment.
By an order dated March 31, 1956, the Deputy Commissioner determined the revised turnover.
An appeal was taken against that order to the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal, Trivandrum, but that appeal was dismissed on March 23, 1957.

Against that order a revision was taken to the Kerala High Court and by its judgment dated September 25, 1958 the High Court set aside the order of the Deputy Commissioner on the ground that the notice issued by the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes was without jurisdiction.
Appeal by special leave to the Supreme Court against the High Court judgment.

legal_issues.text: Whether the notice issued by the Deputy Commissioner was without jurisdiction
Whether the rule under which the Deputy Commissioner purported to act (Rule 17) was ultra vires the Act

petitioner_arguments.text: The notice issued by the Deputy Commissioner was not without jurisdiction and the High Court's opinion on that point is erroneous

respondent_arguments.text: The notice issued by the Deputy Commissioner was without jurisdiction as power to assess escaped turnover is merely incidental to revisional power under s.12(2) and cannot be exercised absent substantive revisional proceedings
If the notice was not without jurisdiction then the rule under which the notice was issued was ultra vires as it was beyond the substantive provisions of the Act

court_reasoning.text: Powers conferred on the Deputy Commissioner under s.12(2) and r.17(3A) are distinct; action under r.17(3A) was not without jurisdiction. Power to assess escaped turnover does not arise out of revisional jurisdiction but is separate under r.17 framed validly under s.19(1),(2)(f).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deputy Commissioner, as revising authority, had power under r.17(3A) to issue notice and determine escaped turnover where no further appeal/revision after Commercial Tax Officer.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 17 is not ultra vires; falls under s.19 rule-making power. Assessing authority under s.9 is for initial assessment; r.17 confers power on revising authority for escaped turnover. No conflict with s.12(2) as separate jurisdictions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sub-rule 3A not confined to pending revisions; plain construction confers jurisdiction independently.

holdings.text: Notice issued by Deputy Commissioner under r.17(3A) was within jurisdiction; High Court judgment erroneous on this point.
Rule 17, including sub-rules 1, 1A, 3A, is valid and intra vires s.19 of the Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: Rule-making power under s.19(1) is general; s.19(2) illustrative and not restrictive.

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs assessment procedure, appeals, revisions, and rule-making for escaped turnover assessment.

statutes_cited.name: Rules under Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Empower assessing, appellate, and revising authorities to assess escaped turnover within 3 years after notice and enquiry.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal by special leave, set aside the Kerala High Court judgment dated September 25, 1958, holding that the notice by Deputy Commissioner was within jurisdiction under r.17(3A) and Rule 17 is intra vires the Act.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside

key_quotes.text: the power to assess escaped turnover does not arise out of the revisional jurisdiction.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes revisional power under s.12(2) from escaped assessment power under r.17

key_quotes.text: r.17 and the various clauses thereof made under s.19 are not beyond the rule making power of the State Government as contained in s.19.
key_quotes.speaker: court
